Reviews.Title: Bower vs. Neewer Grip for 3100
Reviews.Author: Jason Didday
Reviews.Content: I bought both the Bower and the Neewer NEEWER NEW Professional Vertical Battery Grip Holder for Nikon D3100 SLR Digital Camera battery grips and thought I would pass along the comparison to others who might be debating which one to buy.First off, its important to note that at this time, Nikon does not offer a grip for the 3100 and there is no indication that they will.  So aftermarket products are all we have to choose from.  Contrary to popular belief, these are not the same grips - they are very different and the Bower costing almost 3x that of the Neewer. - Both are made in China and both require the cable to activate the vertical shutter release button. - The Bower has a much more substantial, professional feel to the plastic, but neither are as high quality as the Nikon body. - The Bower has a lower profile; the Neewer is 5mm taller. - The Bower's cable is slightly shorter (which is a good thing as it fits better) and thicker which indicates to me, higher quality. - The Bower grip slightly curves and then tapers on the bottom of the grip (when held vertically) which I think looks better than the larger rectangular shape of the Neewer. - The Bower has a wheel to lock the grip to the body that is similar to the wheel Nikon offers on its OEM grips (for other cameras); the wheel on the Neewer is smaller. - The Neewer has a rubber grip on the front side of the grip which I liked; the Bower has nothing. - The Neewer can hold the original Nikon battery cover (which you remove when you install the grip) inside the grip itself - which is nice if you are prone to misplacing small things like that. - The bottom of the Bower has a ribbing similar to the bottom of the Nikon body; the Neewer has nothing. - The Bower has an on/off button for the grip - which I do not completely understand; the Neewer doesn't. - The Bower comes with an infrared remote, which is a nice bonus; the Neewer does not have the remote. - The Bower states on the box that it has "mode adjustment wheel" on the grip - which it does not actually have.Ultimately, even though the Bower cost 3x more than the Neewer, I decided to stay with the Bower.  This is because the plastic and overall build quality is slightly better with the Bower, and the smaller profile fits more to the "smaller" nature of the 3100 than the Neewer.  I can't say its 3x better, and frankly, I think I would've been happy with the Neewer had I never seen the Bower.Hope this helps!

Reviews.Title: Fake
Reviews.Author: ELHERPHA
Reviews.Content: Product arrived totally different than the one your see in the picture,,take careit has only a vertical shutter button and there is no any other controls on this grip, again be aware of this fake photo

Reviews.Title: Don't spend on this one...
Reviews.Author: dookie
Reviews.Content: Cheap Chinese grip.  Physical fit is fine, aesthetic fit is poor (photo in Amazon listing is not accurate).  Appears identical to the "Crazy Cart" grip here (including accessories and manual even):[...]Perfectly functional, but this one is going back.  I'll be d*mned if I'm going to pay $80 for a "name brand" relabeled product that is available at less than 1/2 the cost without the Bower logo.  Neewer is looking even better...cheaper yet, I don't need the remote, and has a rubberized grip surface.Disappointing, at best.

Reviews.Title: WRONG ITEM ON PICTURE
Reviews.Author: thebestphotographer
Reviews.Content: The photo provided for this item is not accurate, VERY disappointed at this item for sale because people are spending a lot of money for something that is totally different coming in the mail. The picture is a battery grip for a CANON dslr by the way!

Reviews.Title: I ordered the Bower grip but recieved a Zeikos grip
Reviews.Author: Ronald Taylor
Reviews.Content: I ordered the Bower grip as it was advertised to have a built in infra red remote for flash. I was substituted a Zeikos grip which I see listed for about 20 dollars less than what I paid and the cord as mentioned in the reviews is a bit too long. I kept the damned thing rather than deal with another screwed up order from Amazon. My satisfaction with them is about 70 percent right now. I probably will purchase most of my photo accessories from Adorama in the future.

Reviews.Title: DO NOT BUY!!!!!
Reviews.Author: James
Reviews.Content: This is the very first item that I have received from Amazon that was not what it was meant to be. This item says and shows that you can make additional adjustments from the grip but this is false. This does not have a grip on it like the camera its actually cheap plastic. Knock off Bower product that is sold at Best Buy. I am so mad about this purchase, I was really looking forward to this product. It actually does work but its cheap feeling and does not do everything that $75 it is asking. Just go to Best buy and buy the real one.  I am sending this crap back, and getting a refund. FALSE ADVERTISEMENT!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: Bower XBGN5100 Battery Grip
Reviews.Author: John Biggerstaff
Reviews.Content: On the whole not bad, but in the vertical position the battery grip button for vertical shoot does not work.May be an issue of the D5100 grip being used on the D5200 camera??????????Small price to pay for the added convenience of double the power.J. Alan BiggerstaffGuelph OntarioCanada

Reviews.Title: Great!
Reviews.Author: Martin T.
Reviews.Content: I can't believe there is no reviews for this product which had me kind of hesitant since I bought the cheap one and it was horrible.  Great product, it works. Some criticisms I would have is that the product looks nothing like the picture. It sits a bit oddly on the D5100. This is a great product and would recommend it to friends. No Lies. It feels cheap, but its performance makes up for that.

Reviews.Title: cheaply made
Reviews.Author: G. Cochran-smith
Reviews.Content: Lightweight plastic feels "cheaply made".  The information about the product doesn't mention that you have to remove the battery compartment door from your camera, as the tower inserts into that compartment.  Other battery grips I've had in the past are external, so I wasn't expecting this.

Reviews.Title: Love this.  Great for my d3100
Reviews.Author: cary p dan
Reviews.Content: Love it, my Nikon d3100 does not have a remote built in and this makes it possible, and with the ability to add an exxtra battery it lasts longer....

Reviews.Title: Nikon D5100 base for all day shooting
Reviews.Author: Paul L. Pruitt
Reviews.Content: Good semi-pro base to add battery life to the D5100.  Light and plastic, but so is the camera. Works well, except for the electronic cord needed to make all the functions work well.  But this in Nikon's way of making the D5100 a less expensive camera.

Reviews.Title: i have to switch the batteries
Reviews.Author: neoprane
Reviews.Content: very useful but i have to switch batteries when the principal one is discharged, it serves more like an extra battery holder and a vertical grip, not sure why it doesn't recognize the other battery. i purchased a original nikon battery

Reviews.Title: it's not the product on the photo
Reviews.Author: Alejandra
Reviews.Content: it is a bower battery grip but you're not paying for the one in the picture... so I recommend that you shouldn't buy this product unless you like the one they send

Reviews.Title: Great Value
Reviews.Author: boostedaudi
Reviews.Content: This does have a cord for the D5100 as the Nikon 5100 does not have the link like some of the higher end cameras have.  If you want to use the flash/shutter release on the front you must have the cord connected.  Looks like it is made by Nikon.

Reviews.Title: Good product but picture is not accurate.
Reviews.Author: Wandering Druid "Allen"
Reviews.Content: The Bower XBGN5100 is a good battery grip.  It is sturdy and fits well to the camera, The batteries fit well and there were no performance problems with the grip.  However the picture on the product page is very misleading.  It is not a picture of the bower grip but of a canon grip so do not judge the product on this picture.

Reviews.Title: Does the job
Reviews.Author: Tab McBlane
Reviews.Content: I bought this hoping it would be better than the NEEWER model but it's not. Still need the cable to activate the camera from the handle, and this one doesn't even have the little cutout on the post to store the door you have to take off. Although the advertiser did not mention this it is on the box that there is an mode adjustment wheel on the handle like there is on the camera for whatever function you would use it for (aperture or exposure). The only thing better about this one over the Neewer model is that the thumb screw wheel is larger and tightens better. Is that worth the extra $40??...nope!Does it work? YesIs it worth the extra money? NopePS: additional info listed on 9/11/13 Something I just found out about this grip and why it is not as good as the Neewer model is this one you have to have the original battery for nikon in the right hand slot and a generic can go in the left hand. When my meter would start reading battery low and I pulled the right battery (nikon) out the camera lost power and came back and said battery not usable with camera because it does not have the chip. Yet take the left battery (generic) out and now my battery meter says full because it is now reading the Nikon battery. So unlike the Neewer grip you must always have a nikon battery in the grip and in the right hand side. The Neewer grip once you power the camera with a nikon battery you can put all generic batteries in and use them as long as the camera never loses power. Once the power has gone dead you will once again need the nikon battery to repower.Now that I know this I would rate this grip at a 1 star, I don't have any idea how they figure you get extended use out of the camera with this setup.  Save your money and buy the Neewer or another brand.
